Topic.Title: Battery life of Motorola Razr M.

Message.Msg: I just checked the talk time. Talked about 34 minutes and it used up between 5% to 6% of battery life. That comes to about 10 to 11 hours talk time. So already the 20 hour is exagerrated. As for 17 days standby time. Who really cares? People don't get smartphones to do nothing for a period of hours, let alone days, let alone over 2 weeks. Not even worth mentioning that efficiency. What's interesting is that surf time was not in specs at best buy website. I'm testing that now by watching a youtube video.

Topic.Title: Battery life of Motorola Razr M.

Message.Msg: Watching youtube, during 15 minutes of video, battery drained by 5% to 6%. That's about 4 to 5 hours of streaming video with a full charge. I also remember in the past doing some surfing the net and playing some video games. That was causing the quickest drain of battery for me at about 1% a minute. That's less than 2 hours on a full charge.

Topic.Title: Battery life of Motorola Razr M.

Message.Msg: Sweetheart, you could have been more helpful. If a phone is draining that much there is a problem, either a hardware fault (return it and get it replaced) or a badly behaved app. Check the battery meter app and it'll tell you where the power is being used.

Topic.Title: Why Haswell is destined for failure

Message.Msg: The cross OS/Cross architecture is one of the big points of geekbench:) Yes, there is an issue using the single number to compare, especially when the number of threads/cores is different. As all the numbers are available you can drill down and compare single threaded results and do real like-for-like. As for Malloc and family on windows 8 - I've no idea - but I do know these tests do show how poor ARM SoC's memory io can be:) There are scores for other Saltwell based SoCs on Android (Z2480 Z2460) and they should have the same memory io interfaces, so you can see if the memory scores are better. What benchmark do you suggest we use instead of geekbench?:)

Topic.Title: PC market decreasing?

Message.Msg: The recent figures are misleading as netbooks were lumped into the PC market when really they were the ancestor of the tablet market and really should have be lumped into that market all along. Atoms are now sold as tablets rather than netbooks often with optional keyboards which fundamentally still makes them a netbook but of course that now means they are no longer registered as a PC sale. This reporting anomaly will disappear next year. p.s. like the way your INTC sentiment flips from bearish to bullish back to bearish depending whether you are long or short at the time. Cute and not in a good way as it exposes you as fundamentally unprincipled and lacking any real conviction or belief either way.

Topic.Title: PC market decreasing?

Message.Msg: You're confusing the issue with terminology

Topic.Title: Why Haswell is destined for failure

Message.Msg: Getting results across OS/architectures is a strong point. Anyone can download and run it, independent of what else is running on their system. The problem is that a benchmark result is a "proxy" for something else. If the score of one machine is 2x another machine, what does it mean? Since geekbench runs a different number of tests on the x86 than ARM, how are the extra tests combined? Does x86 see a benefit or a penalty? I don't know of any benchmark that can be used to compare across OS (stdclib type problems) nor 32-bit versus 64-bit nor CPU architecture where the workloads are different. I will probably whine about this and I appreciate your civil response. IMO, the general model that I have "today" is: ARM is generally faster on FP x86 32-bit is slower because of low number of registers x86_64 alleviates register problem and usually bus width problem. When my preconceived model is violated, I go digging. Just like you do. 8-) BTW, did you get to see the thermal die photos? Search for phrase below and it shows some of the results of Intel's work in power reduction posted on hothardware. I love those thermal die photos that show the die is COLD blue. Thermal images are of Clover Trail, Intel 32nm SoC in active and standby states

Topic.Title: Why Haswell is destined for failure

Message.Msg: March 25, 2013, 3:03 P.M. ET ARMH: Pondering the 64-Bit Server Future Email Print smaller Larger By Tiernan Ray ARM Holdings (ARMH) director of marketing Ian Thornton was in town today and was kind enough to stop by the Barron’s offices. We talked a bit about one of the next substantial frontiers for the company and its partners, 64-bit memory addressing, which is most likely to show up in server and equipment products, although Thornton also had some thoughts on 64-bit in mobile devices, which you can read in an earlier post. ARM’s 64-bit architecture is coming with the “Cortex A50” series, which now exists in microprocessor designs designated “A53″ and “A57.” To give you a sense of the timeline, licenses started to be signed with partners two years ago, and ARM has only lately “taped out” its first microprocessor designs. “They’ve gotten to the Verilog stage, but they’re not quite at the Netlist stage at this point,” says Thornton. That would imply first samples of chips from partners sometime toward the end of this year, with volume production in 2014, notes Thornton. The leading partners signed so far are startup Calxeda, ST-Microelectronics NV (STMPR), Broadcom (BRCM), Samsung Electronics (005930KS), and the semiconductor design unit of China’s Huawei, which makes equipment in addition to mobile devices. There will be a cost and a power savings from the up-front price of these devices as well as the performance they enable in servers and equipment, said Thornton. At this point, though, it’s difficult to quantify all that relative to Intel (INTC) Xeon server processors or Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) Opteron parts because none of the partners has produced a part yet. X86 rules the majority of volume of server shipments today. (Mind you, AMD is also in the ARM camp, see below.) One can make an analogy to Intel‘s “Atom” chip for mobile devices, in comparison to ARM-based smartphone chips based on the “Cortex A9” style parts. Atom takes three times the number of transistors to implement functional blocks that perform similar workloads, a sign of being less efficient than ARM-based designs, for example, contends Thornton. And the Intel x86 architecture uses the “variable length instruction word” approach, making it harder to streamline aspects of what are “monolithic” server processors, in his words. But “that’s just an analogy,” and not really a fair comparison until 64-bit silicon appears, says Thornton. His larger point about the competition between Intel and AMD and ARM partners is that the Intel server world is monolithic in its overall approach. “Today, in some cases, you’ve got just 10% of Xeon being used” in a server, contends Thornton, because the bottleneck is in other parts of the system. If, for example, a server is doing streaming video, and it is mostly passing through bits from an external memory system, then between the time waiting for those bits to come off of a wire, and sending them out to the Internet, the microprocessor itself may not have a lot of work to do. That, says Thornton, suggests that it may be possible for the entire collection of partners — there are 17 licensees of 64-bit ARM, and parties such as Nvidia (NVDA) have talked about getting into servers in a big way — could provide specialized parts that fit the job for different kinds of servers. “It’s almost like an application-specific integrated circuit [ASIC],” quipped Thornton, although in that sense it seems more like an “application specific standard product [ASSP],” I suggested, though in reality such a system-on-a-chip(SOC) might not really be either. Of course, there remain those niggly little details: Software. That huge chunk of the server market running on x86 still uses a lot of legacy applications, such as back-office financial software, even though some workloads have shifted to newer Internet-style applications. Thornton says that when customers tell large application providers such as SAP AG (SAP) or Oracle (ORCL) that they want to run their apps on an ARM-based server, the natural response from the software giants might be “What’s in it for me?” when it comes to all the expense involved in porting software to ARM. Still, he thinks that “eventually everyone comes together to do what’s right for the industry,” which, in ARM’s view, includes moving to ARM processors, obviously. Notes Thornton, there is the open-source software project called Linaro, involving upward of 200 engineers from ARM and its partners, that is helping to standardized Linux for ARM in a variety of contexts, including networking and other equipment. ARM shares today are up $1.35, or 3.4%, at $41.45. Update: Note that I failed to mention above that AMD is also making a push into ARM-based server chips. The company last year bought micro-server designer SeaMicro and has talked extensively about its intentions for ARM-based systems.

Message.Title: INTEL CAN HYPE 14nm but INTEL Business Model Monoply has dismantled by ARMH forever
Message.Msg: MY TRADING Range now tweaked ( $24.50 --$19.50) Old range here was $23-$18 It is not technology but business model. ARM design core only. ARM CPU suppliers design products of the same core thus limited differentiation - price war. If you are a device maker, do you like a CPU supplier listen to you or one never learned to appease its customers (only customers to appease it). Also, INTC's huge overhead on R&D, etc. plus bureaucracy accumulated during its hey days work strongly against it in this environment. People arguing on technical front is like those arguing whether AAPL or GOOG comes with better technology. GOOG wins not on GOOG's technologies but on business model. Samsung fight with AAPL? no matter what, ARM get license fee. -------------- The problem with going to lower nm size is leakage and below 14nm becomes a serious problem, they are rushing and it won't be good. I would not be suprised if Intel would not able to solve 14nm problems in next 5 years since there are a lot of problems involving it. ARM won't die, it does things that Intel does not and since AMD has ARM license now we can expect some amazing products that will hurt Intel. AMD has reserved 28nm fabs from TSMC. Favoring Intel is just criminal, they destroyed the industry with their bribery and rebates. Market is oversaturated with their "high end" products that only yearly give just 10% of improvement. ARM won't be doomed, it seems so called "brokers" and other people yell the same thing as they did with AMD. That is going to die and still AMD din't died and will again give a deserved smack to Intel. When AMD starts getting cash from consoles and other products that they produce I would not be suprised if they buy Zilog or ARM its self, maybe both of them.

Topic.Title: Acer W700 with Dual Boot (Android 4.2.2 and Windows 8)

Message.Msg: The Acer product illustrates my point. When consumers can purchase a tablet that gives them access to both Windows and Android and their respective app ecosystems, hardware benchmarks become less relevant to the purchase decision. Dual boot is an immediate recognizable difference between Intel and ARM based tablets that buyers can understand. Now when the Intel products also deliver the best performing hardware and battery life consumer expectations for tablets will have been reset to what Intel offers. Single OS tablets with limited flexibility will move to the discount table.

Message.Title: Acer Design Event in NY on Friday Was a Nice Lead-in to Tomorrow's Intel Events
Message.Msg: Acer dropped a design first at its event in New York City: a laptop-tablet hybrid with a rotating display that can “float” above the keyboard. The Acer Aspire R7 is certainly unlike any notebook we’ve seen before with a unique “Ezel hinge” that allows the display to move above the keyboard, fold backwards into a presentation display, and even fold into a tablet. Of course, a device this futuristic even has a tie-in with Star Trek. We’ve got everything you need to know about this unique laptop. From digitaltrends [This is just a tiny indication of what is coming and will be hastened by Haswell and Bay Trail in the way of an enormous flood of new form factors and designs. Haswell will open the floodgates and product releases will continue all year and be particularly strong for the holiday season as Intel has a roadmap and pipeline that is chocked full of exciting developments...]

Topic.Title: Wallis, Ashraf, will there be fireworks?

Message.Msg: Hi, nice articles, though why do you need to explain to the ARM bag holders the fault in their investment theory. Sure ARM dominates the phone arena, though as we are finding out there are other areas of expansion ARM is into. Though how successful this will be time will tell. Intel is sure to make a dent into tablet market, especially hurting apple. MS is almost certain to ditch WinRT, apart from tablets, I haven't seen a WinRT notebook, with even the tablets now being offered with discounts and free giveaways to try and shift these lemons. Intel is poised to attain some real penetration in the mobile phone market. What I find interesting of late is the lack of mantra by the analyst "PC is dead, End of the PC era". Simply intel is and will penetrate the fast growing Tablet , and Ultramobile, markets. So much analyst proclamations about how huge the tablet world is expanding and how little intel has a share of this expansion. So much emphasis on intel selling into a shrinking PC market. My point is in the past there was a clear difference between PCs (Desktop, notebook, netbook) and Tablets. Intel simply did not have an acceptable mobile, touch, power efficient, and most importantly fashionable, internet access device. Though intel always had decent devices that could do the math, surf the web, run apps, and lately touch enabled. This month will be different, we WILL have mobile Tablet-PCs, touch, power efficient, and most fashionable, internet access device. So when does a Tablet become a PC? Or, when does a PC become a tablet? ARM camp lemon WinRT and to a lesser extent iPad has proven an ARM powered Tablet CANNOT be a computer. These are simple low power, internet access devices, that are fashionable. For example, lady friend of mine bought iPad a year ago, complete with keyboard, and desktop stand, and now went back to, and uses more her notebook to do the things that are important. Biggest loser in this wave will be Apple, with or without MacTouch.

Topic.Title: Wallis, Ashraf, will there be fireworks?

Message.Msg: Great post. Very telling example from your female friend. MANY of the analysts said the PC was dead to drive the price down.

Topic.Title: Wallis, Ashraf, will there be fireworks?

Message.Msg: To put into perspective I have yet to see any ARM device marketed as a FULLY FUNCTIONAL COMPUTER. Cleaver marketing from ARM tablet vendors imply that these toys are computers, hell you can do anything with them! Right?...UHH WRONG! Intel's needs to step up it's marketing, as in the past it's been abysmal.

Topic.Title: Wallis, Ashraf, will there be fireworks?

Message.Msg: Indeed we are seeing some important changes of the guard: The "End of the PC Era" is giving way to the "Beginning of the Processor Era". And Intel is clearly at the top of the processor food chain with superior technology, fabrication and manufacturing. We are seeing the "End of the iPad Era". Don't get me wrong - the iPad is a fine product and a benchmark in all of computing. But we are finally seeing the end of its complete dominance of the tablet market. Apple has done all it can to milk its shelf life but the iPad is simply slowing down as technology, performance and form factors change and evolve. Windows 8 tablets are showing terrific demand from both consumers and IT professionals who have waited a long time for a performance product. Well, the wait is over. Solutions will now flood the market. Apple has few ways to prolong the dominance of the iPad line. And switching to Intel fabrication is amusingly one of the best available to them. The "End of the ARM Era" is upon us. ARM's fabless model has finally caught up with them and left them without the R&D and new fab money to continue to compete effectively at the high end. ARM 20nm is a year or two out and no one can accurately predict when ARM FinFET solutions will arrive, if ever. The number of ARM foundries has dwindled as a result of the fabless model. ARM's fading fabrication has resulted in the end of the ARM era more than any other factor. These dynamics will likely drive developments for at leas the next several years...

Topic.Title: Why in the world does Intel have Fabs in Israel?

Message.Msg: Intel has one fab in Israel. Fab 28 was built as a 45nm, 300mm fab in 2008 and funded in large part by Israeli government grants and tax concessions. The Israeli government got involved in the 22nm upgrade. In 2012, Israel was responsible for 10% of Intel shipments. It makes a lot of sense from both the brain power and financial point of view.

Topic.Title: MacBook Air Probably Becomes A Convertible

Message.Msg: "My guess is MacBook Air replaces the flailing 10" iPad, and the only think Apple uses its custom SoCs in are the iPad Mini and the iPhone." [Knowing Apple they will probably try to milk the 10 inch iPad as long as possible. Their present course seems to apply this concept across the board with marginal improvements. I'd be surprised to seem them EOL anything until it actually stops getting traction, i.e. making a profit. Until they come out with something big and new, how can they get rid of anything old? I can see them offering a hyrid or convertible MacAir as an additional product. But my real question is when will they redefine the Mac by creating a hybrid of Mac OS X and iOS with a built-in keyboard and a touch screen. I just read an article where all the Mac fanbois said a notebook or Ultrabook would never ever ever need a touch screen because a mouse works so great. But, um, who carries a mouse all of the time or wants to dig one out? I think the absence of a touch screen product hurts them. So, unless they plan on giving up the whole MacBook line it seems that they have to move in some direction. I'm not holding my breath. I'm hugely disappointed with Apple and Tim Cook. Everything in Apple's line seems to be winding down. iPads winding down. iPhone declining dramatically in growth rates. Apple is losing the "cool" factor and once that's gone it will be big trouble in River City. Well, Cupertino I guess...]

Topic.Title: MacBook Air Probably Becomes A Convertible

Message.Msg: Being that the Mac Book Air is tapered, if they can criss cross the ends to give the consumer a flat tablet, it can be a powerful cool looking laptop or a very slim tablet that may be just slightly thicker than the iPad. They will slightly price it higher than existing Mac Book Air prices. Maybe about $100 more. However, as the iPod still exists due to a much lower price point, so will the iPad. So the Mac Book Air convertibles will be about $1100 starting price while the Mac Book Air may drop to $900 starting price. A market will still be for them to have a much cheaper iPad. But the iPad will slow down in sales depending on the popularity of the convertible. Similar to what is currently happenning to the iPod because of the iPhone's success. Mac Book convertible will have to have an Intel processor in it, but for the long term continuing success of the iPad, Apple has to build it around Intel processors as well. Either that or seriously drop the price by 50%. I think they will pick the higher price point with Intel processors.

Topic.Title: Why in the world does Intel have Fabs in Israel?

Message.Msg: Most of the earthquake risk, according to the USGS, seems to be concentrated in the last 1,600,000 years. A few faults have had activity in the last 780,000 years and none during the last 20,000 years. There are some small fault lines in Washington County Oregon. That is the county Hillsboro is located. None of the faults that have been active for the last 20,000 years. There are a couple of small fault lines that have had activity in the 780,000 years. Most fault lines have had activity in the last 1,600,000 years.

Message.Title: Samsung galaxy S4 overheating rumors spreading on social media
Message.Msg: From thenewstribe . from comments section, seems to be translated from Chinese site which contains an interesting you t u b e video showing unusual heat generated from S4 phones youtubeDOTcom/watch?v=XqssJdMXjvI LONDON: Social media especially Twitter is after Samsung galaxy S4 these days because just after the launch of the new S4 many users are experiencing an overheating issue with the device and they are expressing their concern openly and blatantly which is going against the marketing campaign of Samsung galaxy S4. Sources say that these days many shoppers are using social media to decide whether they should buy S4, Sony Xperia, HTC one or iPhone 5. And when they listen to social media,they find many users of Samsung galaxy S4 complaining about the device. They discover that there are numerous mentions of Samsung’s Galaxy S4 devices which are suffering from overheating issues. The flagship device, which has to fight with likes of HTC One and Apple iPhone 5 is in the fiercely contested smartphone market,however,has so far the Samsung device has generated only negative PR. The commentators say that this overheating issue is not going to help the product in the market. Thought it is true that the overheating issue is not that unusual and it is common observation that all the devices heat up after a certain amount of time,however,what YouTuber SuperFreshTech and others have found is that the brand-new Samsung device perhaps warms up a little more than ordinary. Now potentially shoppers are a little cautious about the future of the product They have doubt that there may be some inherent fault in the design of the Samsung Galaxy S4.Lets see how Samsung brand custodians tackle the situation.

Message.Title: Who Has the Best Roadmap?
Message.Msg: Intel/ARM Roadmap Comparison Intel (All FinFET): 22nm: Haswell June 2013 14nm: Broadwell: End of 2013/Start of 2014 14nm: Skylake: 2015 10nm: Skymont: 2016 7nm: 2018 5nm: 2020 ARMH Planar 28nm: Production has been increasing but is still insufficient to meet market demand. Substantially all of the production is coming from TSMC, which is a significant bottleneck. 20nm: Volume production in 2014/2015. TSMC has promised to ramp 20nm faster than 28nm but this appears to be nothing more than rhetoric as 20nm will be yet another level of complexity when trends have show each successive ARM die shrink to ramp significantly slower than the previous. FinFET 14/16nm: ARM foundries will pursue a half-step to FinFET by making it half FinFET and half 20nm. This clearly illustrates their lack of confidence in bringing a full step online in a reasonable time frame. There are so many unknowns with the half-step process, that any prediction of volume production cannot be reliably made. Conclusions 1.) Intel will continue to have significant opportunities for high margin foundry work, as illustrated by the Altera deal. 2.) Intel's fabrication economics will continue to improve just as ARM's are degrading. ARMs 20nm planar and the half-step to FinFET both have inferior economics to the Intel nodes. 3.) Intel will reach 450mm wafer implementation well ahead of ARM, giving them significantly improved economic benefits. Intel's lead in fabrication and manufacturing is increasing in virtually every area.
